title: 112_s662
content: The "Natural Resources Restoration Act of 2011" is also known as the Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill Damage Assessment under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990. The "Natural Resources Restoration Act of 2011" defines key terms related to the Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill, including the Administrator, Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill, Panel, and Trustee. The Administrator will arrange for the National Academies to convene a panel of scientists to evaluate natural resource damages from the Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill. The panel will prepare a report estimating the cost of restoring the natural resources. The panel of scientists will estimate the cost of restoring natural resources damaged by the Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill and compensating for the loss of natural resource services during the restoration period. The total estimated costs for all trustees will be considered in the report. The panel will consider results of a study from the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2010 and information from the natural resources damages assessment for the Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill. A preliminary draft must be prepared within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The panel will prepare a preliminary draft of the report within 90 days of the Act's enactment. A 30-day comment period will follow for trustees and responsible parties to provide feedback on the draft report. The panel will submit a final report to Congress and publish it in the Federal Register within 30 days after the comment period ends. A special assessment will be conducted for natural resource damages related to the Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill. A special assessment will be conducted for natural resource damages related to the Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill, including restoring natural resources and compensating for loss of natural resource services. The assessment amount will be determined based on the cost of restoration and compensation, as estimated in a report. The responsible parties will pay a mutually agreed amount for special assessments to restore natural resources impacted by the Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill. The trustees will use these funds for restoration projects in accordance with applicable law. The assessment under subparagraph (A) will be conducted in accordance with laws and regulations related to natural resource damages assessment and restoration, including public participation. Credits will be applied towards any other natural resource damages for the Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill. The Administrator will establish regulations promptly after the enactment of this section. The Administrator will establish regulations for a program where responsible parties can buy credits for projects carried out by a trustee.
